Quoting from #4684:

/--
We put a partial order on ‚ÑÇ so that `z ‚â§ w` exactly if `w - z` is real and nonnegative.
Complex numbers with different imaginary parts are incomparable.
-/
instance : partial_order ‚ÑÇ :=
{ le := Œª z w, ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, 0 ‚â§ x ‚àß w = z + x,
...
Are there any other candidates for which we might want to use results from the order library?

I am not sure whether this is relevant or not, but there are partial orderings on ‚ÑÇ, different than the one above that appear in the literature. For instance, when talking about Bridgeland stability conditions, (partially) ordering complex numbers by a choice of argument appears often. One example, is on page 2 of the paper below, with even an explanatory picture:

https://www.maths.ed.ac.uk/~abayer/dc-lecture-notes.pdf

Well it's not just a matter of whether there is any better order to put on the complexes. Not putting an order on the complexes should also be an option. Sometimes I think that we're undermining the benefits of type theory when we make everything apply to everything like this; I'm reminded of the incident where nat had a has_coe_fn to nat -> nat
My rationale is that if you ask a mathematician "are the complexes ordered" the answer you will get is "no"
I guess my ancient functional analysis origins are showing. I would have said "yes". :-)
I have seen this particular order before, I think in coq or mizar, but it seems more like a formalization trick than anything else
It's the standard ordering on any Banach *-algebra or C*-algebra, specialised to the smallest example of such.
is there a wiki link for this?

Just to clarify: what I meant by my comment is that I personally would not consider the complex numbers to be ordered, but I am happy with someone saying "for this section, I am going to order the complex numbers as follows: [...]". Whether they use the "lexicographic-like" stuff with the reals, arguments, norms, or whatever else is less relevant (to me!).

So, from this point of view, I believe that my position is close to Mario's.
wikipedia does indeed say the ordering is only on the self-adjoint elements
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C*-algebra#Structure_of_C*-algebras
Okay, I'll agree that extending the partial order, rather than just the self-adjoint elements, is not particularly important or useful.
It's useful for the sake of formalisation, because you don't need to carry around witnesses of self-adjointness when talking about the ordering of self-adjoint elements.
well that should be some kind of subspace. Of course this is pretty explicit for real

That said I'm sympathetic to the formalization argument and I won't fight too hard on this. I just want to double check that this isn't another division by zero kind of thing that will require us to defend the choice to aghast mainstream mathematicians all the time
or maybe nat subtraction is a better parallel
I'm pretty sure this is no where near as aghasting as monus.
Are we talking about making this a global instance? I think most mathematicians expect C not to have an order
Ok! How should I hide it away?

Like Bryan said, another option is to have this be an instance in a locale. That means you would say open_locale complex_order or something like that and it would add local attribute [instance] complex.partial_order and so on
Done!

Reviving this question briefly: someone pointed out to me recently that it is completely standard to write 0 ‚â§ z in informal mathematics, when z is a complex number to mean "z is real and non-negative".

When the partial_order ‚ÑÇ discussed above is available, it is possible to do exactly this in Lean too.
@Scott Morrison do you have particular reasons against using a locale?
Doesn't that give us the best of both worlds?
It's also possible to write I <= z with that partial order, and I'm not sure what this actually means would be in the top 3 guesses if you showed this to a random mathematician
(that said, we are of course no strangers to definitions that make sense in a limited range and give pseudo-sensible results out of range)
Right, we should just define I <= z to mean z = 37 whenever z is non-real :stuck_out_tongue_wink: /s
It's even pretty sensible: I <= z means z-I is a positive complex number, ie a positive real.
I don't have my heart set on making this instance global. I just wanted to say that I'd realised people use it naturally.
ooh, ok :thumbs_up:
Ah great, then we can finally write x ‚â§ 0 ‚à® 0 ‚â§ x instead of im x = 0.

I would advise against making local(ized) instances for notation classes. This might get confusing because the pretty-printer will always print it as x ‚â§ 0, but Lean can't parse x ‚â§ 0 unless the locale is opened.
In a similar vein, I think it would be just as confusing if we had multiple instances for has_le ‚ÑÇ.
I am not convinced that this type class is a good idea. But if we have it, I think it should be global.

In Scott's example you could just say (z : ‚Ñù) (h : 0 ‚â§ z) or even (z : ‚Ñù‚â•0) instead of (z : ‚ÑÇ) (h : 0 ‚â§ z) and then use coercions. And the coercion allows simp lemmas to trigger, while the hypothesis doesn't (as easily).

{ s : ‚ÑÇ | I * s ‚â§ I * 1 / 2 ‚à® I * 1 / 2 ‚â§ I * s }

i.e.

Œ∂ (s) = 0 ‚Üí I * s ‚â§ I * 1 / 2 ‚à® I * 1 / 2 ‚â§ I * s

x ‚â§ s ‚à® s ‚â§ x ‚Üî im x = im s
Gabriel, indeed, that is what I was trying to achieve! Ahaha

I view this partial order as uncountably many incomparable orders, one for each imaginary part. On a given line with a fixed imaginary part, you simply compare the real parts. This is what it is, right?
yes
To be honest, I am not thrilled about this order, but I am also unlikely to actually ever seriously use an order on ‚ÑÇ, so I am happy to go with whatever makes formalizing simpler.
There is another order on the complexes that I have used before, namely lexicographic order of (re z, im z)
which has the advantage of being total
The one in question is closer to lex on (im z, re z), except that the order on im is inexistent: you can only compare something with itself.
It coincides with both
The given partial order is a subset of both total orders (re z, im z) and (im z, re z)
Yes, you are right: this is so confusing for me! :upside_down:
Personally it makes more sense to me to sort the numbers -1, -I, 0, I, 1 in that order
like if I had a whole random collection of complex numbers and wanted to arrange them lex order seems the easiest to follow

My tutees just taught me the "jungle river metric" on ‚Ñù^2, which has similar features (although it does allow you to change the x coordinate, but at a cost).
(You should view the x-axis as a river and you can only travel vertically or along the river, so to go from (a,b) to (c,d) you first go vertically to the x-axis, then you slide on the river and finally you move vertically again)

With #6210 (see also this thread), the IsROrC class will now extend PartialOrder, so that we can have a StarOrderedRing instance for IsROrC. However, this would entail making the existing scoped PartialOrder ‚ÑÇ instance a global instance (x ‚â§ y ‚Üî x.re ‚â§ y.re ‚àß x.im = y.im). The question is: is that okay?

/poll Can we make the PartialOrder ‚ÑÇ instance global?
yes
no

What would be the arguments against making this instance global?

Of course, one shouldn't use ‚â§\le‚â§ on C\mathbb{C}C too much in the first place... But when it is used in math, I think it is almost always in exactly the sense (x ‚â§ y ‚Üî x.re ‚â§ y.re ‚àß x.im = y.im) that Jireh describes.

Trying to force myself to think of some other mathematically reasonable meaning and use of ‚â§\le‚â§ on C\mathbb{C}C, I could only come up with "two-dimensional cumulative distribution functions determining a Borel (probability) measure on C\mathbb{C}C", in which case the reasonable choice of partial order would be (x ‚â§ y ‚Üî x.re ‚â§ y.re ‚àß x.im ‚â§ y.im). But I doubt this other partial order should be a global instance. (For that purpose we have Fin 2 ‚Üí ‚Ñù, I guess.)

Kalle, turning your comments into an argument against it would go something like this:

"there are other partial orders we may want to consider on ‚ÑÇ from time to time; e.g., two-dimensional cumulative distribution functions determining a Borel (probability) measure on ‚ÑÇ result in the pointwise order (x.re ‚â§ y.re ‚àß x.im ‚â§ y.im). If the instance suggested by the poll is made global, then to use this alternative partial order we would have to disable it locally."

I'm not saying I support that argument, but you asked for an argument against it.

What would be the arguments against making this instance global?

That the order is surprising for people who aren't paying attention, I guess. Perhaps you wrote z < w but meant to write norm z < norm w or z.re < w.re.
If you think the complex partial order is stupid, then you will be annoyed that this silently did the wrong thing instead of giving you an error.

Eric, I think what you're suggesting is probably (IMHO) the best argument against it. Although I think where it might be most confusing is if you wanted norm z < norm w (or something related), but for some reason they were coerced to ‚ÑÇ; then Lean doesn't complain, but you didn't get what you expected and it is sometimes easy to miss a ‚Üë in the goal.
A good example of another family of scoped instances is the one that sets {1} + {2, 3} = {3, 4}; that's disabled behind the Pointwise locale, even though its the "obvious" instance

I totally agree that the partial order is completely stupid, and indeed am savage with undergraduates when they write z‚â§wz\leq wz‚â§w for complex numbers, but what I am unclear about is whether this instinct is a reasonable basis for arguing against not making the instance global. 6 years ago I would have also argued that 1/0=01/0=01/0=0 is also completely stupid and I have now made my peace with this idea having better understood the nature of Lean's type theory.
Kevin, do you think a partial order instance on H ‚ÜíL[‚ÑÇ] H with H a Hilbert space is also stupid? (the order is propositionally the same as f‚ÇÅ ‚â§ f‚ÇÇ iff f‚ÇÇ - f‚ÇÅ is positive semidefinite.)

A more mathematical comment: a few months ago when thinking about this order I wanted to dismiss it out of hand because everyone knows that (a) there's a standard proof which shows that there's no sensible order on the complexes ("squares are nonnegative and -1 is negative") and hence (b) the complexes are a field and a ring, and this order will not make them an ordered field or an ordered ring, and thus it's a terrible idea. However the argument for (a) shows that there is no total order on the complexes which is compatible with the ring structure (squares are nonnegative because you check the two cases x>=0 and x<0, so the argument doesn't apply to iii which is neither > 0 nor < 0) and (b) when I actually started to think about it, the axioms you come up with are satisfied anyway; for example a‚â§ba\leq ba‚â§b and c‚â§dc\leq dc‚â§d doesn't imply ac‚â§bdac\leq bdac‚â§bd, but this isn't true for the reals either; you have to demand 0‚â§a0\leq a0‚â§a and 0‚â§c0\leq c0‚â§c to make this work, and this is true for the complexes with the proposed order. So even though my gut feeling is that this is horrible, I cannot mathematically justify this and so I might just be wrong.

Jireh I have never seen that ordering in my life but perhaps my answer is: if it is a partial order which satisfies 0‚â§10\leq 10‚â§1, and if a‚â§ba\leq ba‚â§b and c‚â§dc\leq dc‚â§d implies a+c‚â§b+da+c\leq b+da+c‚â§b+d, and if it also satisfies ac‚â§bdac\leq bdac‚â§bd under the additional assumptions 0‚â§a0\leq a0‚â§a and 0‚â§c0\leq c0‚â§c then I cannot really find a mathematical objection to it.

Kevin, it's the standard order on selfadjoint elements, but extended to be defined on all elements by requiring that the imaginary parts are equal. It definitely doesn't satisfy a * c ‚â§ b * d if 0 ‚â§ a and 0 ‚â§ c because it lacks commutativity (this is partly why a StarOrderedRing is in general not an OrderedRing).
ac‚â§bc‚â§bdac\leq bc\leq bdac‚â§bc‚â§bd?
both of those inequalities fail
Oh interesting. Just to be clear we're assuming 0‚â§a0\leq a0‚â§a here, which implies that the imaginary part of aaa is zero. This doesn't help? This is what saves us in the complexes.
Right, but ‚ÑÇ is commutative. The product of positive operators is positive if and only if they commute. (Essentially because that's what's needed to make the product selfadjoint)

Thanks everyone for much better arguments than I had in mind!

After these, I do like Eric's balanced vote for both yes and no :rofl:, but I think the self-adjoint use case is so dear to me that I vote for whatever makes it the most convenient (which I believe is Jireh's proposed instance).

Kevin the inequality that holds in a StarOrderedRing is docs#conjugate_le_conjugate a ‚â§ b ‚Üí star c * a * c ‚â§ star c * b * c. (with our definition, this holds for all a b c, but mathematically you should think of a b as being self-adjoint and c as being anything). When your ring is commutative and positive elements (things of the form star c * c) have positive square roots, then you can get 0 ‚â§ c ‚Üí a ‚â§ b ‚Üí c * a ‚â§ c * b because sqrt c exists (and is positive, hence selfadjoint too) and c * a = sqrt c * a * sqrt c ‚â§ sqrt c * b * sqrt b = c * b.
As I said in another thread, the thing that really sold this order to me is the fact that it‚Äôs the natural order coming from the star algebra structure.

I see I even upvoted Kevin's message against the instance in that thread, but I think that message gave the impression of using a ‚â§ b as an obscure form of hypothesis, which I don't think it would be in clear enough operator-theory context.

(But I'm slightly torn: the "readable to any mathematician not familiar with mathlib" is a strong argument, and Eric's position seems ever more tempting. :balance: )
By the way, maybe I‚Äôve been influenced by Lean too early, but I don‚Äôt remember ever seeing the order on operators being restricted to self adjoint elements ü§î

As far as readability is concerned, I'm skeptical that this will really be a problem, even in the context of Kevin's message. For example, I think it's totally natural for a mathematician to say that z : ‚ÑÇ is positive (they mean z ‚àà Set.range ((‚Üë) : ‚Ñù‚â•0 ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ)), which is just phrased as 0 ‚â§ z with this partial order instance. Likewise, to say z : ‚ÑÇ is not positive just means z ‚àâ Set.range ((‚Üë) : ‚Ñù‚â•0 ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (or ¬¨ (0 ‚â§ z).

The only small footgun I see in that regard is that ¬¨ (0 ‚â§ z) is not equivalent to z < 0, but of course that's to be expected since ‚ÑÇ isn't a linear order.
